title: How to Make Vegetable Fritters

steps.headline: Chop or grate 4 cups (600 grams) of your desired vegetables.
steps.description: Hard vegetables, such as potatoes, carrots, and broccoli, work the best. Soft vegetables, such as mushrooms or tomatoes, might not work as well. You can use just one type of vegetable or a combination of different ones. Whatever you decide to do, plan on having 4 cups (600 grams) total. Grate the following vegetables: butternut squash, carrots, parsnips, potatoes, sweet potatoes, or turnips. Chop the following vegetables: broccoli or cauliflower.

steps.headline: Cook the vegetables in the microwave.
steps.description: Place the vegetables into a microwave-safe container. Cover them with a wet paper towel. Cook chopped vegetables for 2 to 3 minutes. Cook grated vegetables for 1 minute. This will cook the vegetables slightly. They will cook the rest of the way in the pan.

steps.headline: Add the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description:
Transfer the cooked vegetables into a large mixing bowl first. If you'd like, you can cut the chopped vegetables into finer pieces or pulse them in food processor for a few seconds. Add in the cheese, flour, eggs, salt, and pepper. Cheese that works especially well in fritters includes:
Cheddar, Jack, and Mexican blend
Feta or Goat
Mozzarella
Swiss or Gruyere

steps.headline: Stir everything together with a rubber spatula.
steps.description: The batter should be thin enough so that you can ladle it out, but not so thin that it spreads easily. If it is too thick or dry, add more eggs. If it is too wet, add more flour or cheese.

steps.headline: Heat some oil in a large skillet.
steps.description: Place a large skillet on the stove. Turn the heat up to medium-high. Let the pan become hot enough to sizzle water. Add some oil into the pan and swirl it around to coat the pan's surface.

steps.headline: Ladle some batter onto the pan.
steps.description: Use ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Depending on how big your pan is, you may be able to fit more than one fritter. Avoid crowding the pan, however, or they won't cook properly.

steps.headline: Cook the fritters for 4 to 6 minutes, turning once.
steps.description: Cook the fritters for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip them over using a spatula. Cook them for another 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Place the fritters onto a wire cooling rack as you finish them.
steps.description: To protect your counter and catch the grease, place the wire cooling rack onto a baking sheet first. Set the finished fritters onto the rack. To keep the fritters warm, place the entire baking sheet into an oven set to 250°F (121°C).

steps.headline: Serve the fritters.
steps.description: They go great with sour cream, Greek yogurt, or maple syrup.

steps.headline: Soak the chia seeds in water.
steps.description: Pour the chia seeds into a small bowl. Add 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of water. Place the bowl into the fridge for 15 minutes. Don't have any chia seeds? Use 1 tablespoon (6.6 grams) of ground flax seeds instead.

steps.headline: Peel and grate your vegetables.
steps.description: Wash and peel the zucchini, potatoes, and onion. Grate each of them and toss them into a large mixing bowl. Consider salting the zucchini first, and then squeezing it in a clean dishcloth. This will get rid of the excess liquid. Your fritters will be less soggy.

steps.headline: Add in the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description: Add in the flour, breadcrumbs, parsley, and soaked chia seeds. Season the batter with some salt and pepper. For extra flavor, add in some garlic powder and pepper flakes. Don't have any whole wheat flour? Use more breadcrumbs or all-purpose flour. Don't have breadcrumbs? Use more flour.

steps.headline: Stir everything together with a rubber spatula.
steps.description: Keep stirring until everything is evenly combined. Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of your bowl often.

steps.headline: Heat some oil in a large skillet.
steps.description: Set a large skillet down on the stove and turn the heat up to medium-high. Let the skillet become hot, then add some oil. Tilt the pan around until the oil evenly coats its surface.

steps.headline: Ladle the batter onto the skillet.
steps.description: Plan on using about ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Depending on the size of your skillet, you may need to work in several batches.

steps.headline: Fry the fritters for 4 to 6 minutes, turning once.
steps.description: Let the fritter cook for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip the fritter over with a spatula, then let it cook for 2 to 3 minutes more.

steps.headline: Place the finished fritters onto a wire cooling rack set atop a baking sheet.
steps.description: You can keep these fritters warm by placing the them (with the ire cooling rack and baking sheet) into a warm oven (about 250°F/121°C).

steps.headline: Serve the fritters while they are still warm.
steps.description: These fritters go especially well with avocado-based sauce.

steps.headline: Wash, peel, and grate the zucchinis.
steps.description: Alternatively, you can peel and seed the zucchinis, then pulse them in a food processor for a few seconds. This will give you a smoother patty.

steps.headline: Salt and strain the zucchinis.
steps.description: Spread a clean dishcloth on the counter. Add the shredded zucchinis on top. Season the zucchinis with salt. Wrap the dishcloth around the zucchinis, like a lollipop. Squeeze the bundle over a sink. This will strain out the excess water and make your fritters less soggy.

steps.headline: Combine the zucchinis with the rest of the ingredients.
steps.description: Put the zucchini into a large mixing bowl. Add the beaten eggs, the thinly-sliced green onions, almond flour, and the freshly grated Parmigiano Reggiano. Season with some salt and freshly ground black pepper. Need a vegan option? Mix 2 tablespoons (13.2 grams) flax meal with 6 tablespoons (90 milliliters) of warm water. Let it sit in the fridge for about 15 minutes, then add it in.

steps.headline: Stir everything together, and add some lemon juice, if desired.
steps.description: Use a rubber spatula to mix everything together. Scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often to ensure that all the ingredients get mixed in evenly.

steps.headline: Heat some oil in a large skillet.
steps.description: Place a skillet on the stove, and turn the heat up to medium. Add in 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of your favorite cooking oil. When the oil starts to sizzle, the pan is hot and ready for fritters. Great oil choices include: avocado, coconut, and walnut.

steps.headline: Ladle spoonfuls of batter onto the skillet.
steps.description: Plan on using about ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Don't try to fit all of the fritters on one pan; plan on making them in batches. If you crowd the pan, the fritters won't cook properly.

steps.headline: Cook the fritters for 2 to 3 minutes per side.
steps.description: Let the fritters fry for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip them over with a spatula. Let them cook for another 2 to 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer the fritters to a wire cooling rack.
steps.description: Place the wire cooling rack on a baking sheet first. As you finish the fritters, set them down onto the wire cooling rack. This will allow the fritters to drain and prevent them from getting soggy. Keep the fritters warm by placing the entire baking sheet into a warm oven (about 250°F/121°C).

steps.headline: Serve the fritters.
steps.description: These fritters go especially well with sour cream and thinly sliced green onions. You can also serve them with some applesauce for a twist.

text:
Making Basic Vegetable Fritters Chop or grate 4 cups (600 grams) of your desired vegetables. Hard vegetables, such as potatoes, carrots, and broccoli, work the best. Soft vegetables, such as mushrooms or tomatoes, might not work as well. You can use just one type of vegetable or a combination of different ones. Whatever you decide to do, plan on having 4 cups (600 grams) total. Grate the following vegetables: butternut squash, carrots, parsnips, potatoes, sweet potatoes, or turnips. Chop the following vegetables: broccoli or cauliflower. Cook the vegetables in the microwave. Place the vegetables into a microwave-safe container. Cover them with a wet paper towel. Cook chopped vegetables for 2 to 3 minutes. Cook grated vegetables for 1 minute. This will cook the vegetables slightly. They will cook the rest of the way in the pan. Add the rest of the ingredients. Transfer the cooked vegetables into a large mixing bowl first. If you'd like, you can cut the chopped vegetables into finer pieces or pulse them in food processor for a few seconds. Add in the cheese, flour, eggs, salt, and pepper. Cheese that works especially well in fritters includes:
Cheddar, Jack, and Mexican blend
Feta or Goat
Mozzarella
Swiss or Gruyere Stir everything together with a rubber spatula. The batter should be thin enough so that you can ladle it out, but not so thin that it spreads easily. If it is too thick or dry, add more eggs. If it is too wet, add more flour or cheese. Heat some oil in a large skillet. Place a large skillet on the stove. Turn the heat up to medium-high. Let the pan become hot enough to sizzle water. Add some oil into the pan and swirl it around to coat the pan's surface. Ladle some batter onto the pan. Use ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Depending on how big your pan is, you may be able to fit more than one fritter. Avoid crowding the pan, however, or they won't cook properly. Cook the fritters for 4 to 6 minutes, turning once. Cook the fritters for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip them over using a spatula. Cook them for another 2 to 3 minutes. Place the fritters onto a wire cooling rack as you finish them. To protect your counter and catch the grease, place the wire cooling rack onto a baking sheet first. Set the finished fritters onto the rack. To keep the fritters warm, place the entire baking sheet into an oven set to 250°F (121°C). Serve the fritters. They go great with sour cream, Greek yogurt, or maple syrup. Making Vegan Vegetable Fritters Soak the chia seeds in water. Pour the chia seeds into a small bowl. Add 3 tablespoons (45 milliliters) of water. Place the bowl into the fridge for 15 minutes. Don't have any chia seeds? Use 1 tablespoon (6.6 grams) of ground flax seeds instead. Peel and grate your vegetables. Wash and peel the zucchini, potatoes, and onion. Grate each of them and toss them into a large mixing bowl. Consider salting the zucchini first, and then squeezing it in a clean dishcloth. This will get rid of the excess liquid. Your fritters will be less soggy. Add in the rest of the ingredients. Add in the flour, breadcrumbs, parsley, and soaked chia seeds. Season the batter with some salt and pepper. For extra flavor, add in some garlic powder and pepper flakes. Don't have any whole wheat flour? Use more breadcrumbs or all-purpose flour. Don't have breadcrumbs? Use more flour. Stir everything together with a rubber spatula. Keep stirring until everything is evenly combined. Be sure to scrape the bottom and sides of your bowl often. Heat some oil in a large skillet. Set a large skillet down on the stove and turn the heat up to medium-high. Let the skillet become hot, then add some oil. Tilt the pan around until the oil evenly coats its surface. Ladle the batter onto the skillet. Plan on using about ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Depending on the size of your skillet, you may need to work in several batches. Fry the fritters for 4 to 6 minutes, turning once. Let the fritter cook for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip the fritter over with a spatula, then let it cook for 2 to 3 minutes more. Place the finished fritters onto a wire cooling rack set atop a baking sheet. You can keep these fritters warm by placing the them (with the ire cooling rack and baking sheet) into a warm oven (about 250°F/121°C). Serve the fritters while they are still warm. These fritters go especially well with avocado-based sauce. Making Gluten Free Vegetable Fritters Wash, peel, and grate the zucchinis. Alternatively, you can peel and seed the zucchinis, then pulse them in a food processor for a few seconds. This will give you a smoother patty. Salt and strain the zucchinis. Spread a clean dishcloth on the counter. Add the shredded zucchinis on top. Season the zucchinis with salt. Wrap the dishcloth around the zucchinis, like a lollipop. Squeeze the bundle over a sink. This will strain out the excess water and make your fritters less soggy. Combine the zucchinis with the rest of the ingredients. Put the zucchini into a large mixing bowl. Add the beaten eggs, the thinly-sliced green onions, almond flour, and the freshly grated Parmigiano Reggiano. Season with some salt and freshly ground black pepper. Need a vegan option? Mix 2 tablespoons (13.2 grams) flax meal with 6 tablespoons (90 milliliters) of warm water. Let it sit in the fridge for about 15 minutes, then add it in. Stir everything together, and add some lemon juice, if desired. Use a rubber spatula to mix everything together. Scrape the bottom and sides of the bowl often to ensure that all the ingredients get mixed in evenly. Heat some oil in a large skillet. Place a skillet on the stove, and turn the heat up to medium. Add in 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of your favorite cooking oil. When the oil starts to sizzle, the pan is hot and ready for fritters. Great oil choices include: avocado, coconut, and walnut. Ladle spoonfuls of batter onto the skillet. Plan on using about ¼ cup (60 milliliters) of batter per fritter. Don't try to fit all of the fritters on one pan; plan on making them in batches. If you crowd the pan, the fritters won't cook properly. Cook the fritters for 2 to 3 minutes per side. Let the fritters fry for 2 to 3 minutes. Flip them over with a spatula. Let them cook for another 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer the fritters to a wire cooling rack. Place the wire cooling rack on a baking sheet first. As you finish the fritters, set them down onto the wire cooling rack. This will allow the fritters to drain and prevent them from getting soggy. Keep the fritters warm by placing the entire baking sheet into a warm oven (about 250°F/121°C). Serve the fritters. These fritters go especially well with sour cream and thinly sliced green onions. You can also serve them with some applesauce for a twist.
